in alcohol for three days, and then cutting it up into 
very small pieces, extracting with glycerol, and 
filtering. On the addition of alcohol to the filtrate,
the ferment is precipitated. The action of this ferment 
on starch was the complete conversion of the latter 
into glucose. The action of the ferment on fibrin was 
the formation of leucin and tyrosin; for on treat-
ing the fermented mass with hot water and filter-
ing, a solution was obtained which contained 
leucin and tyrosin. When acetic acid was added 
to this solution, acicular crystals were deposited.
These crystals were insoluble in ether, but soluble 
in boiling water. The aqueous solution produced 
a red flocculent precipitate on the addition of a 
neutral solution of mercuric nitrate; this re-
action is characteristic of tyrosin.
The acetic acid solution, after precipitating the 
tyrosin, was evaporated, when leucin was deposited 
in white shining plates. These crystals of leucin 
were heated with barium oxide - the result
